sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy of extended-release ciprofloxacin (Cipro(R) XR) have not been established for treatment of infections other than UTIs
  • immediate-release and extended-release oral dosage forms are not interchangeable
  • patients initiated on ciprofloxacin IV therapy may be switched to oral ciprofloxacin when clinically indicated
  • a desensitization schedule for ciprofloxacin hypersensitivity has been developed by 1 institution
  • Anthrax: 400 mg IV every 12 hours; duration of therapy, 60 days (guideline dose)
  • Anthrax: 500 mg orally every 12 hours; duration of therapy, 60 days (guideline dose)
  • Bacteremia associated with intravascular line: Ochrobacterium anthropi: 400 mg IV every 12 hours (guideline dose)
  • Bacterial meningitis: 800 to 1200 mg/day IV in divided doses every 8 to 12 hours (guideline dose)
  • Bacterial prostatitis, chronic: Mild to moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 28 days
  • Bacterial prostatitis, chronic: Mild to moderate: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 28 days
  • Bacterial sinusitis, acute: Mild to moderate: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Bacterial sinusitis, acute: Mild to moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations: Mild to moderate: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations: Mild to moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations: Severe or complicated: 400 mg IV every 8 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations: Severe or complicated: 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Cat scratch disease: 500 mg orally twice daily for 10 to 16 days (study dose)
  • Chancroid: 500 mg orally twice a day for 3 days (guideline dose)
  • Febrile neutropenia, Empiric therapy: 400 mg IV every 8 hours for 7 to 14 days, in combination with piperacillin 50 mg/kg IV every 4 hours (maximum 24 g/day)
  • Gonorrhea, Uncomplicated: 250 mg orally as a single dose (manufacturer dose); fluoroquinolones are no longer recommended for the treatment of gonorrhea (guidelines).
  • Granuloma inguinale: 750 mg orally twice daily for at least 21 days and until healing of lesions is complete (guideline dose)
  • HIV infection - Salmonella gastroenteritis: Mild disease with or without symptomatic bacteremia: 500 to 750 mg orally twice daily or 400 mg IV twice daily; duration of 7 to 14 days if CD4+ count is at least 200/mcL, 2 to 6 weeks if CD4+ count is less than 200/mcL, or at least 6 months for recurrent symptomatic septicemia (guideline dose)
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: Mild or moderate: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: Mild or moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: Severe or complicated: 400 mg IV every 8 hours for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint: Severe or complicated: 750 mg orally every 12 hours for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: Mild to moderate: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: Mild to moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: Severe or complicated: 400 mg IV every 8 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue: Severe or complicated: 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Infectious diarrheal disease: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 5 to 7 days
  • Infectious disease of abdomen, Complicated: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days, in combination with metronidazole
  • Infectious disease of abdomen, Complicated: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days, in combination with metronidazole
  • Infective cholangitis - Sepsis: 200 mg IV every 12 hours then 750 mg orally every 12 hours; duration, 2 to 10 days for IV therapy and 4 to 6 days for oral (study dosing)
  • Infective endocarditis: Native valve, culture-negative: 500 mg orally or 400 mg IV every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV every 12 hours AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks (guideline dosing)
  • Infective endocarditis: Prosthetic valve (late, longer than 1 year), culture-negative: 500 mg orally or 400 mg IV every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 15 mg/kg IV every 12 hours AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks AND rifampin 300 mg IV or orally every 8 hours for 6 weeks (guideline dosing)
  • Infective endocarditis: Native and prosthetic valve endocarditis caused by HACEK microorganisms: 500 mg orally or 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 4 to 6 weeks (guideline dosing)
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 60 days
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 60 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: Mild to moderate: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: Mild to moderate: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: Severe or complicated: 400 mg IV every 8 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Lower respiratory tract infection: Severe or complicated: 750 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Nosocomial pneumonia: 400 mg IV every 8 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Plague: Contained casualty setting: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 10 days; switch to oral when clinically indicated (guideline dose)
  • Plague: Mass casualty setting: 500 mg orally twice daily for 10 days (guideline dose)
  • Plague: Postexposure prophylaxis: 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (guideline dose)
  • Pyelonephritis, acute, Uncomplicated: (Extended-release tablets) 1000 mg orally once daily for 7 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing); duration of 7 days (guideline dosing)
  • Tularemia: Contained casualty (bioterrorism) setting: 400 mg IV every 12 hours for 10 days (guideline dose)
  • Tularemia: Mass casualty (bioterrorism) setting/postexposure prophylaxis: 500 mg orally twice daily for 14 days (guideline dose)
  • Typhoid fever: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 10 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Severe or complicated: 400 mg IV every 8 to 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Severe or complicated: (Immediate-release oral suspension) 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Severe or complicated: (Extended-release tablets) 1000 mg orally once daily for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Uncomplicated: Mild to moderate: 200 mg IV every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Uncomplicated: (Oral suspension) Mild to moderate: 250 mg orally every 12 hours for 7 to 14 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Uncomplicated: (Oral suspension) Acute cystitis: 250 mg orally every 12 hours for 3 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Uncomplicated: (Extended-release tablets) Acute cystitis: 500 mg orally once daily for 3 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy of ciprofloxacin IV or oral suspension not established in pediatric patients except when used for the treatment of complicated UTIs and pyelonephritis in children 1 to 17 years of age or postexposure prophylaxis for inhalational anthrax
  • safety and effectiveness of extended-release ciprofloxacin (Cipro(R) XR) have not been established in pediatric patients
  • doses of 4 to 40 mg/kg per day (median 15 mg/kg/day in low-birth-weight (less than 1500 g) neonates have been used to treat infections with multidrug-resistant gram-negative organisms
  • Anthrax: 10 to 15 mg/kg IV (MAX 400 mg/dose) every 12 hours; duration of therapy, 60 days (guideline dose)
  • Anthrax: 10 to 15 mg/kg orally every 12 hours (MAX 1 g/day); duration of therapy, 60 days (guideline dose)
  • Infective endocarditis: Native valve, culture-negative: 10 to 15 mg/kg IV or orally (MAX dose 400 mg IV or 500 mg orally) every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 40 mg/kg/day IV in 2 or 3 equally divided doses AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks (guideline dosing)
  • Infective endocarditis: Prosthetic valve (late, longer than 1 year) culture-negative: 10 to 15 mg/kg IV or orally (MAX dose 400 mg IV or 500 mg orally) every 12 hours, in combination with vancomycin 40 mg/kg/day IV in 2 or 3 equally divided doses AND gentamicin sulfate 1 mg/kg IV/IM every 8 hours, for 4 to 6 weeks AND rifampin 20 mg/kg/day IV or orally in 3 equally divided doses for 6 weeks (guideline dosing)
  • Infective endocarditis: Native and prosthetic valve endocarditis caused by HACEK microorganisms: 10 to 15 mg/kg IV or orally (MAX dose 400 mg IV or 500 mg orally) every 12 hours for 4 to 6 weeks (guideline dosing)
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 10 mg/kg IV every 12 hours for 60 days; MAX 400 mg/dose
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 15 mg/kg orally every 12 hours for 60 days; MAX 500 mg/dose
  • Plague: Contained casualty setting: 15 mg/kg IV every 12 hours for 10 days; switch to oral when clinically indicated (guideline dose)
  • Plague: Mass casualty setting: 15 mg/kg orally twice daily for 10 days (guideline dose)
  • Plague: Postexposure prophylaxis: 15 mg/kg orally twice daily for 7 days (guideline dose)
  • Pyelonephritis, Complicated: (1 to 17 years) 6 to 10 mg/kg IV every 8 hours for 10 to 21 days; MAX 400 mg/dose, even with body weight more than 51 kg
  • Pyelonephritis, Complicated: (1 to 17 years) 10 to 20 mg/kg orally every 12 hours for 10 to 21 days; MAX 750 mg/dose, even with body weight more than 51 kg
  • Tularemia: Contained casualty (bioterrorism) setting: 15 mg/kg IV every 12 hours for 10 days (guideline dose)
  • Tularemia: Mass casualty (bioterrorism) setting/postexposure prophylaxis: 15 mg/kg orally twice daily for 14 days (guideline dose)
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Severe or complicated: (1 to 17 years) 6 to 10 mg/kg IV every 8 hours for 10 to 21 days; MAX 400 mg/dose, even if patient weighs more than 51 kg
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Severe or complicated: (1 to 17 years) 10 to 20 mg/kg orally every 12 hours for 10 to 21 days; MAX 750 mg/dose, even if patient weighs more than 51 kg

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (CrCl greater than 30 mL/min): IV; no dosage adjustment necessary; alternatively, (CrCl 31 to 60 mL/min/1.73 m(2)) 400 mg every 12 hours
  • renal impairment (CrCl 5 to 29 mL/min): IV; 200 to 400 mg IV every 18 to 24 hours; alternatively, (CrCl less than 30 mL/min/1.73 m(2)) 400 mg every 24 hours
  • renal impairment (CrCl greater than 50 mL/min): oral suspension; no dosage adjustment necessary
  • renal impairment (CrCl 30 to 50 mL/min): oral suspension; 250 to 500 mg every 12 hours
  • renal impairment (CrCl 5 to 29 mL/min): oral suspension; 250 to 500 mg every 18 hours
  • hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis: oral suspension; 250 to 500 mg every 24 hours, after dialysis
  • renal impairment (severe) with severe infection: oral suspension; a unit dose of 750 mg may be used, given either every 12 hours (CrCl 30 to 50 mL/min), every 18 hours (CrCl 5 to 29 mL/min), or every 24 hours (patients on hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis, give dose after dialysis)
  • renal impairment (CrCl 30 mL/min or less and treated for complicated UTI or acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis): extended-release tablets; 500 mg orally daily; use of 1000-mg tablets not recommended
  • hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis: extended-release tablets; maximum dose 500 mg orally every 24 hours administered after dialysis; use of 1000-mg tablets not recommended
  • hepatic impairment: dosage adjustments are not needed in patients with cirrhosis
  • geriatrics: with normal renal function, no dosage adjustment is necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Bacterial prostatitis, chronic
  • Bacterial sinusitis, acute
  • Bronchitis, chronic, acute exacerbations
  • Febrile neutropenia, Empiric therapy
  • Gonorrhea, Uncomplicated
  • Infection of bone - Infectious disorder of joint
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Infectious diarrheal disease
  • Infectious disease of abdomen, Complicated
  • Inhalational anthrax, Postexposure; Prophylaxis
  • Lower respiratory tract infection
  • Nosocomial pneumonia
  • Pyelonephritis, acute, Uncomplicated
  • Pyelonephritis, Complicated
  • Typhoid fever
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Severe or complicated
  • Urinary tract infectious disease, Uncomplicated
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Anthrax
  • Antibiotic enterocolitis
  • Atypical mycobacterial infection
  • Bacteremia associated with intravascular line
  • Bacterial meningitis
  • Cat scratch disease
  • Chancroid
  • Cholera
  • Crohn's disease
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
  • Granuloma inguinale
  • HIV infection - Salmonella gastroenteritis
  • Infection AND/OR inflammatory reaction due to internal prosthetic device, implant AND/OR graft
  • Infection by Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Infective cholangitis - Sepsis
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Meningitis, Multidrug resistant
  • Meningococcal infectious disease
  • Operation on gastrointestinal tract, Colorectal - Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis
  • Otorrhea (Chronic)
  • Peritonitis
  • Plague
  • Providencia stuartii infection
  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia infection, Pseudomonas maltophilia
  • Transrectal biopsy of prostate
  • Transurethral resection of the prostate
  • Tuberculosis
  • Tularemia

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
• Intravenous (Solution)
    Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, are associated with an increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture in all ages. Risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart, or lung transplants. Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, may exacerbate muscle weakness in persons with myasthenia gravis. Avoid in patients with known history of myasthenia gravis.
  • Oral (Tablet, Extended Release; Suspension)
    Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, are associated with an increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture in all ages. Risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart, or lung transplants. Fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, may exacerbate muscle weakness in persons with myasthenia gravis. Avoid in patients with known history of myasthenia gravis.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant tizanidine administration
  • hypersensitivity to ciprofloxacin or any product component, or other quinolones

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- avoid use in patients with myasthenia gravis as muscle weakness may be exacerbated; ventilatory support requirement and death have been reported
  • -- tendinitis and tendon rupture have been reported and may occur bilaterally within first 48 hours, during, or several months after completing therapy, especially in age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart, or lung transplant; discontinue therapy at fist sign of tendon pain, swelling, inflammation, or rupture
  • Cardiovascular:
  • -- QT prolongation, including rare cases of torsade de pointes, have been reported; avoid use with known QT prolongation, uncorrected hypokalemia, and with class IA (quinidine, procainamide), or class III (amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmic agents
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- avoid excessive exposure to sunlight or UV light as moderate or severe phototoxicity/photosensitivity may occur; discontinue if phototoxicity occurs
  • Hepatic:
  • -- severe hepatotoxicity, including cases of fatal hepatic necrosis and hepatic failure, has been reported; onset is rapid ranging from 1 to 39 days and often associated with hypersensitivity with increased risk for fatal outcomes in age over 55 years; discontinue immediately if hepatitis is suspected
  • Immunologic:
  • -- hypersensitivity, including serious or fatal reactions, has occurred; discontinue at first sign of rash, jaundice, or other signs or symptoms of hypersensitivity
  • Musculoskeletal:
  • -- patients with history of tendon disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, may be at increased risk for tendon rupture
  • Neurologic:
  • -- convulsions, increased intracranial pressure, and toxic psychosis have been reported, especially with known or suspected CNS disorders (eg, epilepsy and severe cerebral arteriosclerosis) or other risk factors (eg, renal dysfunction and certain drug therapy) that may predispose to seizures or lower seizure threshold
  • -- sensory or sensorimotor axonal polyneuropathy have been reported; discontinue if patient experiences symptoms of neuropathy
  • -- peripheral neuropathy has been reported with oral and injectable fluoroquinolones and may occur any time during therapy and persist for months to years or become permanent even after discontinuation; discontinue if symptoms occur and switch to a non-fluoroquinolone unless benefit outweighs risk
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- ophthalmic preparation is for topical use only; do not inject into eye
  • Renal:
  • -- patients with renal dysfunction may be at increased risk for seizures and tendon rupture with renal failure
  • -- dosage adjustment is necessary in patients with renal impairment
  • -- alkalinized urine has rarely resulted in crystalluria
  • Other:
  • -- elderly patients are at increased risk of QT prolongation
  • -- pediatric patients are at increased risk for adverse events related to joints and surrounding tissues
  • -- local site reactions may occur with infusion time of 30 minutes or if small veins of hand are used; administer IV by slow infusion over 60-minutes
  • -- strenuous physical activity may increase risk of tendon rupture
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- avoid theophylline; if concomitant use is required, monitoring and dosage adjustment may be warranted
  • -- avoid milk products or calcium-fortified juices with oral administration

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • WHO: Avoid breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (up to 1.8%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (1.6% to 4.8%), Nausea (2.5% to 4%), Vomiting (1% to 4.8%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (oral extended-release tablets, 3%; IV, greater than 1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiorespiratory arrest (up to 1%), Myocardial infarction (up to 1%), Prolonged QT interval, Syncope (up to 1%), Torsades de pointes
  • Dermatologic:Photosensitivity (up to 1%), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (up to 1%), Toxic epidermal necrolysis (up to 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile diarrhea (up to 1%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (up to 1%), Pancreatitis (up to 1%), Pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Hematologic:Agranulocytosis, Aplastic anemia, Bone marrow depression, Hemolytic anemia, Leukopenia (0.4%), Pancytopenia (0.1%), Thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic:Hepatic necrosis (up to 1%), Hepatitis (up to 1%), Hepatotoxicity, Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (up to 1%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myasthenia gravis, Exacerbation, Rupture of tendon, Tendinitis
  • Neurologic:Raised intracranial pressure, Seizure (up to 1%)
  • Ophthalmic:Retinal detachment
  • Psychiatric:Depression (up to 1%), Psychotic disorder (up to 1%)
  • Renal:Acute renal failure (up to 1%), Hemorrhagic cystitis (up to 1%)

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: The bactericidal action of ciprofloxacin results from interference with the enzyme DNA gyrase, which is needed for the synthesis of bacterial DNA. .

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 1 to 2 hr (immediate release); 1 to 4 hr (extended release)
  • Bioavailability, oral: 60% to 80%
  • Effect of food: minimal

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd: 1.2 to 2.7 L/kg
  • Protein binding, serum proteins: 20% to 40%

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: 30% to 57% (immediate-release); 35% (extended-release tablets)
  • Renal clearance: 300 mL/min
  • Fecal: 20% to 35%
  • Bile: small amount recovered from the bile as unchanged drug; 1% to 2% recovered from the bile in the form of metabolites.
  • Dialyzable: Yes

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• 3 to 6 hours (immediate-release); approximately 6 to 7 hours (extended-release tablets).
  • 2.73 hr (neonates); 1.28 hr (children (1 to 5 yr of age))

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
• Intravenous
    • dilute in D5W, NS, or LR to concentration of 1 to 2 mg/mL, infuse over 60 minutes by either direct IV infusion or through a Y-type IV infusion set
    • do not administer any other solution during infusion when using Y-type (piggyback) administration
  • Oral
    • (oral suspension) do not administer through feeding tubes due to its physical characteristics
    • (oral suspension) take with or without food; do not take with milk, yogurt, or calcium-fortified juice; but may be taken with meals that contain these products
    • (oral suspension) swallow completely, do not chew microcapsules
    • (suspension) shake well before measuring dose; do not administer through enteral or nasogastric feeding tube
    • (oral suspension and extended-release tablets) if given together, take 2 hours before or 6 hours after antacids containing magnesium or aluminum, sucralfate, didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution, other highly buffered drugs, polymeric phosphate binders (eg, sevelamer, lanthanum carbonate), or products containing calcium, iron, or zinc
    • (extended-release tablets) avoid concomitant use with dairy products alone, or with calcium-fortified products; separate substantial calcium intake (greater than 800 mg) by at least 2 hours
    • (extended-release tablets) swallow whole; do not split, crush, or chew

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• systemic infection: fever, symptomatic improvement
  • systemic infection: renal function
  • systemic infection: CBC

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    • Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/100 ML, 400 MG/200 ML, 10 MG/ML
    • Oral Powder for Suspension: 250 MG/5 ML, 500 MG/5 ML
  • Amerinet Choice Ciprofloxacin
    Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/100 ML
  • Cipro IV
    Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/100 ML, 400 MG/200 ML, 10 MG/ML
  • Cipro
    Oral Powder for Suspension: 250 MG/5 ML, 500 MG/5 ML
  • NovaPlus Ciprofloxacin
    Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/100 ML, 400 MG/200 ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Instruct patient to immediately report symptoms of tendonitis or tendon rupture (pain, swelling, inflammation of tendon), especially if elderly and/or using concomitant steroids.
  • Tell patient to immediately report symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, including pain, burning, tingling, or numbness.
  • Advise patient to use sunscreen, avoid tanning beds, and avoid excessive exposure to sunlight as drug causes phototoxicity.
  • Counsel patient to avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness and lightheadedness.
  • Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, rash, headaches, confusion, restlessness, or injection site reactions.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report severe diarrhea, dermatologic reactions (toxic epidermal necrolysis, Stevens-Johnson), or symptoms of hepatitis.
  • Advise patient to immediately report CNS events (hallucinations, depression, suicidal thoughts, or convulsions).
  • Oral: Warn patient to avoid taking drug alone with dairy products (milk, yogurt) or calcium-fortified juice. The drug may be taken with meals that contain these items.
  • Oral: Advise patient to take drug 2 hours before or 6 hours after magnesium or aluminum-containing antacids or products containing calcium, iron, or zinc.
  • Advise patient to avoid caffeine during therapy due to enhanced caffeine effects.
